Ranil Wickremesinghe

Ranil Wickremesinghe is a Sri Lankan politician who has served as the Prime Minister of Sri Lanka on six occasions and as the President of Sri Lanka from 2022 to 2024. He is a member of the United National Party (UNP) and has been a key figure in Sri Lankan politics for over four decades.

#Early life and education

Ranil Wickremesinghe was born on March 24, 1949, in Colombo, Sri Lanka. He comes from a prominent family of politicians and lawyers. His father, Esmond Wickremesinghe, was a lawyer and a politician who served as a member of the State Council of Ceylon. Wickremesinghe's maternal grandfather, D.R. Wijewardena, was a prominent lawyer and politician who served as a member of the Legislative Council of Ceylon.

Wickremesinghe received his primary education at Royal College, Colombo, and later attended the University of Ceylon, where he studied law. He graduated with a degree in law and was called to the bar in 1972.

#Political career

Ranil Wickremesinghe's entry into politics was influenced by his family's involvement in politics. He joined the United National Party (UNP) in 1967 and quickly rose through the ranks. In 1977, he was elected to the Parliament of Sri Lanka from the Biyagama electorate.

##Batalanda incident

In 1990, Wickremesinghe was embroiled in a controversy surrounding the Batalanda detention center, where hundreds of prisoners were allegedly tortured and killed. Wickremesinghe, who was then the Minister of Education, was accused of being involved in the cover-up of the incident. Although he denied any involvement, the incident damaged his reputation and led to widespread criticism.

##First premiership (1993–1994)

In 1993, Wickremesinghe became the Prime Minister of Sri Lanka for the first time, succeeding Dingiri Banda Wijetunga. During his first premiership, Wickremesinghe implemented several economic reforms, including the privatization of state-owned enterprises and the liberalization of trade policies.

##Opposition (1994–2001)

In 1994, Wickremesinghe's government was defeated in the parliamentary elections, and he became the Leader of the Opposition. During this period, he led the opposition to the government of Chandrika Kumaratunga, who had implemented several populist policies that Wickremesinghe opposed.

###1999 presidential election

In 1999, Wickremesinghe contested the presidential election against Chandrika Kumaratunga. Although he polled well, he lost the election due to the support of the Janatha Vimukthi Peramuna (JVP) and the Jathika Hela Urumaya (JHU) for Kumaratunga.

##Second premiership (2001–2004)

In 2001, Wickremesinghe became the Prime Minister of Sri Lanka for the second time, after the UNP won the parliamentary elections. During his second premiership, Wickremesinghe implemented several economic reforms, including the signing of the Ceasefire Agreement with the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam (LTTE).

###Peace talks

In 2002, Wickremesinghe initiated peace talks with the LTTE, which had been waging a separatist war against the government since the 1980s. Although the talks were initially successful, they broke down in 2003 due to disagreements over the implementation of the Ceasefire Agreement.

##Opposition (2004–2015)

In 2004, Wickremesinghe's government was defeated in the parliamentary elections, and he became the Leader of the Opposition for the second time. During this period, he led the opposition to the government of Mahinda Rajapaksa, who had implemented several authoritarian policies that Wickremesinghe opposed.

###2005 presidential election

In 2005, Wickremesinghe contested the presidential election against Mahinda Rajapaksa. Although he polled well, he lost the election due to the support of the JVP and the JHU for Rajapaksa.

###Dissent within the UNP

In 2011, Wickremesinghe faced a leadership challenge from within the UNP, led by Karu Jayasuriya and Sajith Premadasa. Although the challenge was ultimately unsuccessful, it weakened Wickremesinghe's position within the party.

###End of the civil war and 2010 presidential election

In 2009, the Sri Lankan civil war ended with the defeat of the LTTE. In 2010, Wickremesinghe contested the presidential election against Mahinda Rajapaksa, who was seeking re-election. Although Wickremesinghe polled well, he lost the election due to the support of the JVP and the JHU for Rajapaksa.

##Third, fourth and fifth premierships (2015–2019)

In 2015, Wickremesinghe became the Prime Minister of Sri Lanka for the third time, after the UNP won the parliamentary elections. During his third premiership, Wickremesinghe implemented several economic reforms, including the introduction of a new constitution and the establishment of a national unity government.

###Foreign policy

During his third premiership, Wickremesinghe implemented a foreign policy that was more aligned with the West. He strengthened relations with the United States and the European Union, and he supported the United Nations' resolution on human rights in Sri Lanka.

###Government bonds controversy

In 2015, Wickremesinghe was embroiled in a controversy surrounding the issuance of government bonds, which were allegedly sold at a high interest rate to a company linked to the Prime Minister's friend, Arjuna Mahendran. Although Wickremesinghe denied any involvement, the incident damaged his reputation and led to widespread criticism.

##Opposition (2019–2022)

In 2019, Wickremesinghe's government was defeated in the presidential election, and he became the Leader of the Opposition for the third time. During this period, he led the opposition to the government of Gotabaya Rajapaksa, who had implemented several populist policies that Wickremesinghe opposed.

##Sixth premiership (2022)

In 2022, Wickremesinghe became the Prime Minister of Sri Lanka for the sixth time, after the resignation of Mahinda Rajapaksa. During his sixth premiership, Wickremesinghe implemented several economic reforms, including the introduction of a new economic plan and the establishment of a national unity government.

#Presidency (2022–2024)

In 2022, Wickremesinghe became the President of Sri Lanka, after the resignation of Gotabaya Rajapaksa. During his presidency, Wickremesinghe implemented several economic reforms, including the introduction of a new economic plan and the establishment of a national unity government.

##Crackdown on anti-government protests

In 2022, Wickremesinghe's government was criticized for its crackdown on anti-government protests, which were sparked by the economic crisis. Although Wickremesinghe denied any involvement, the incident damaged his reputation and led to widespread criticism.

Killing of Jayland Walker

Jayland Walker was a 25-year-old American man who was shot and killed by police officers in Akron, Ohio, on June 27, 2022. The incident sparked widespread protests and raised concerns about police brutality and systemic racism in the United States.

#Background

Jayland Walker was born on December 16, 1996, in Akron, Ohio. He grew up in the city and attended Buchtel High School. After high school, Walker worked as a DoorDash delivery driver and was known to his friends and family as a kind and gentle person. Walker was also an avid music lover and enjoyed playing the guitar and writing songs.

In the months leading up to his death, Walker had been struggling with depression and anxiety. His family and friends reported that he had been seeking help and was taking medication to manage his symptoms.

#Incident

On June 27, 2022, at around 12:30 a.m., Walker was driving his car in the downtown area of Akron when he was stopped by police officers. The officers were responding to a report of a suspicious vehicle, and Walker's car allegedly matched the description.

According to police reports, Walker did not immediately stop his car and instead led the officers on a brief chase. Walker eventually pulled over, and the officers approached his vehicle. Walker then allegedly got out of his car and began to run away from the officers.

The police officers, who were later identified as Justin Franks, Ryan White, and Michael Pirkle, among others, chased after Walker and attempted to apprehend him. During the chase, the officers used their tasers and pepper spray on Walker, but he continued to run.

At around 12:45 a.m., the officers cornered Walker in a parking lot and opened fire, shooting him multiple times. Walker was pronounced dead at the scene.

#Investigation

The Akron Police Department immediately launched an investigation into the shooting, which was led by the Ohio Bureau of Investigation (BBI). The BBI collected evidence from the scene, including body camera footage from the officers involved, and interviewed witnesses.

The investigation found that the officers had shot Walker a total of 46 times, with some bullets striking him in the back and others in the face and torso. The report also noted that Walker was unarmed at the time of the shooting.

In July 2022, the Akron Police Department released a report detailing the events leading up to Walker's death. The report stated that Walker had been driving erratically and had failed to stop for the police officers. article:
Boys Planet

Boys Planet is a 2023 South Korean reality competition television series that premiered on Mnet on February 2, 2023. The show is a large-scale project that brings together 98 male trainees from various entertainment agencies to compete for a spot in a new K-pop boy group. The series is a follow-up to the successful Girls Planet 999, which aired in 2021.

**Concept and format**

Boys Planet features a unique concept and format, where 98 trainees are divided into three groups: K-Group, J-Group, and G-Group, representing Korea, Japan, and Global, respectively. The trainees undergo various challenges and evaluations, including singing, rapping, dancing, and acting, to showcase their skills and talents. The contestants compete against each other in a series of missions, and the top performers are selected to move on to the next round.

## Voting system

The voting system on Boys Planet is a combination of online votes, expert judges' scores, and peer evaluations. Viewers can vote for their favorite contestants through the Mnet Plus app, while expert judges and peer evaluators assess the contestants' performances based on their skills and teamwork. The voting results are announced at the end of each episode, and the contestants with the lowest scores are eliminated.

**Promotion and broadcast**

Boys Planet is broadcast on Mnet every Thursday at 8 PM KST, starting from February 2, 2023. The show is also available to stream on various online platforms, including Mnet Plus, YouTube, and V Live.

## Broadcast schedule

The broadcast schedule for Boys Planet is as follows:

* Episodes 1-3: Introduction and Group Evaluations
* Episodes 4-6: Position Evaluations

* Episodes 10-12: Final Evaluations and Debut Lineup Announcement

**Contestants**

**Ranking**

The third voting period on Boys Planet takes place from March 16 to March 30, 2023. The contestants compete in concept evaluations, and the top performers are selected to move on to the next round.

The result of Boys Planet is announced on April 6, 2023. The top 9 contestants are selected to debut as a new K-pop boy group.

article:
2023 The Hundred Season

The 2023 season of The Hundred is the third edition of the Hundred, a professional franchise 100-ball cricket tournament in England and Wales. The tournament features eight teams, with both men's and women's competitions running concurrently.

#Teams

The eight teams participating in the 2023 season are:

* Birmingham Phoenix
* London Spirit
* Manchester Originals
* Northern Superchargers
* Oval Invincibles
* Southern Brave
* Trent Rockets
* Welsh Fire

#Tournament structure

The tournament structure remains the same as the previous season, with each team playing eight group-stage matches. The top three teams from each group qualify for the knockout stages, with the top team earning a direct spot in the final. The second and third-placed teams compete in the eliminator match to determine the second finalist.

#Squads

##Women

Each team has a 15-member women's squad, with a mix of international and domestic players. Some notable signings include:

* Birmingham Phoenix: Amy Jones, Kirstie Gordon
* London Spirit: Tammy Beaumont, Deandra Dottin
* Manchester Originals: Kate Cross, Sophie Ecclestone
* Northern Superchargers: Lauren Winfield-Hill, Alice Davidson-Richards
* Oval Invincibles: Suzie Bates, Marizanne Kapp
* Southern Brave: Anya Shrubsole, Stafanie Taylor
* Trent Rockets: Natalie Sciver, Katherine Brunt
* Welsh Fire: Hayley Matthews, Georgia Hennessy

##Men

Each team has a 15-member men's squad, with a mix of international and domestic players. Some notable signings include:

* Birmingham Phoenix: Liam Livingstone, Moeen Ali
* London Spirit: Zak Crawley, Mark Wood
* Manchester Originals: Jos Buttler, Lockie Ferguson
* Northern Superchargers: Faf du Plessis, Wahab Riaz
* Oval Invincibles: Sam Curran, Sunil Narine
* Southern Brave: Jofra Archer, Quinton de Kock
* Trent Rockets: Dawid Malan, Rashid Khan
* Welsh Fire: Jonny Bairstow, Ollie Pope

##Replacements

Teams can make replacements to their squads due to injury or other reasons. Some notable replacements include:

* Birmingham Phoenix: Chris Woakes (replaced by Tom Helm)
* London Spirit: Ravi Bopara (replaced by Matt Critchley)

#Format

The 100-ball format features two teams, each facing 100 balls. Each match is divided into innings, with each team facing 10 overs of 10 balls each. The team with the higher score at the end of the 100 balls wins the match.

#Broadcasting

The tournament is broadcast live on Sky Sports and the BBC. Sky Sports has exclusive rights to broadcast all matches live, while the BBC broadcasts selected matches live and provides highlights packages.

Lahaina, Hawaii

Lahaina is a historic town located on the western coast of the island of Maui, Hawaii. Once the capital of the Kingdom of Hawaii, Lahaina is now a popular tourist destination known for its rich cultural heritage, stunning natural beauty, and vibrant arts scene. This article provides an overview of Lahaina's history, geography, demographics, arts and culture, sports, and popular culture.

# History

Lahaina's history dates back to the early 19th century, when it was a major center of commerce, politics, and culture in Hawaii.

## Name

### Modern name, etymology and pronunciations

The modern name "Lahaina" is derived from the Hawaiian words "la" meaning "sun" and "haina" meaning "cruel" or "relentless". The name is often pronounced as "lah-HY-nah" or "lah-HAH-nah".

### Ancient names

Before the arrival of Westerners, Lahaina was known by several ancient names, including "Lele" and "Mokuhinia". These names referred to the area's fertile lands, abundant resources, and strategic location.

## Early rulers

Lahaina was an important center of power and politics in ancient Hawaii. The area was ruled by a series of ali'i (chiefs) and monarchs, including Kahekili II, who established Lahaina as the capital of Maui in the late 18th century.

## Western contact

### Kahekili II

In 1786, Lahaina was visited by British explorer George Vancouver, who was received by Kahekili II. The meeting marked the beginning of Western contact with Lahaina and had significant consequences for the area's history.

### Kamehameha I and Kamehameha II

In the early 19th century, Kamehameha I, the founder of the Kingdom of Hawaii, conquered Maui and established Lahaina as his royal capital. Kamehameha II, his son and successor, continued to rule from Lahaina until his death in 1824.

### Christian missionaries

In 1820, Christian missionaries arrived in Lahaina, led by Hiram Bingham. The missionaries had a profound impact on the area, introducing Christianity, Western education, and modern agriculture.

### Whaling

During the 19th century, Lahaina became a major whaling port, with hundreds of ships visiting the area each year. The whaling industry brought significant economic growth and cultural change to Lahaina.

### Kamehameha III

In 1825, Kamehameha III, the grandson of Kamehameha I, ascended to the throne and established Honolulu as the new capital of the Kingdom of Hawaii. Although Lahaina was no longer the capital, it remained an important cultural and economic center.

### 20th century

In the 20th century, Lahaina experienced significant growth and development, driven by the tourism industry. The area became known for its historic sites, cultural attractions, and natural beauty.

## 2023 wildfire

On August 8, 2023, a devastating wildfire broke out in Lahaina, forcing thousands of people to evacuate and causing widespread damage. The fire was eventually brought under control, but not before it had destroyed hundreds of homes and businesses.

# Geography

Lahaina is located on the western coast of Maui, approximately 20 miles northwest of Kahului. The area is bounded by the West Maui Mountains to the east and the Pacific Ocean to the west.

## Climate

Lahaina has a tropical savanna climate, with warm temperatures and moderate humidity throughout the year. The area experiences a dry season from April to October and a wet season from November to March.

# Demographics

As of the 2020 census, the population of Lahaina was approximately 12,702 people. The area is diverse, with a mix of Native Hawaiians, Caucasians, Asians, and other ethnic groups.

# Arts and culture

Lahaina is known for its vibrant arts scene, with numerous galleries, museums, and cultural attractions. The area is home to the Lahaina Heritage Trail, a self-guided walking tour that explores the area's history and culture.

# Sports

Lahaina is a popular destination for outdoor enthusiasts, with numerous beaches, parks, and recreational facilities. The area is also home to the Lahaina Civic Center, which hosts a variety of sports and cultural events throughout the year.

# Popular culture

Lahaina has been featured in numerous films, television shows, and books, including the popular TV show "Hawaii Five-O" and the novel "The Descendants" by Kaui Hart Hemmings.

# Notes

* This article is based on general knowledge and does not include specific citations or references.

article:
Tornado Outbreak of March 21–23, 2022

A significant tornado outbreak occurred across the southern United States from March 21 to 23, 2022, producing a total of 83 confirmed tornadoes across nine states. The outbreak caused widespread damage and resulted in at least six fatalities.

# Meteorological Synopsis

The outbreak was caused by a strong low-pressure system that developed over the southern Great Plains on March 20. The system intensified as it moved eastward, producing a strong cold front that swept across the region. Moist air from the Gulf of Mexico interacted with the cold front, creating a volatile mix of warm, moist air near the surface and cooler, drier air aloft. This led to the development of strong thunderstorms, some of which produced tornadoes.

## March 21

On March 21, the Storm Prediction Center (SPC) issued a moderate risk (4/5) of severe thunderstorms for parts of the southern Great Plains, including Oklahoma, Texas, and Kansas. As the day progressed, multiple tornadoes touched down across the region, including a long-lived EF2 tornado that affected several counties in Oklahoma.

## March 22

On March 22, the SPC issued a high risk (5/5) of severe thunderstorms for parts of the Southeast, including Alabama, Georgia, and the Florida Panhandle. The risk area included several major cities, including Birmingham, Atlanta, and Tallahassee. As the cold front moved eastward, multiple tornadoes touched down across the region, including several long-lived EF3 tornadoes.

## March 23

On March 23, the SPC issued a moderate risk (4/5) of severe thunderstorms for parts of the Mid-Atlantic, including North Carolina, Virginia, and Maryland. As the cold front continued to move eastward, multiple tornadoes touched down across the region, including a long-lived EF2 tornado that affected several counties in North Carolina.

# Confirmed Tornadoes

A total of 83 tornadoes were confirmed across nine states during the outbreak.

## March 21 Event

A total of 23 tornadoes were confirmed on March 21, including:

* Oklahoma: 11 tornadoes, including a long-lived EF2 tornado that affected several counties
* Texas: 6 tornadoes, including an EF1 tornado that damaged several homes in the Dallas area
* Kansas: 4 tornadoes, including an EF1 tornado that touched down in the Kansas City area
* Arkansas: 2 tornadoes, including an EF1 tornado that damaged several homes in the Little Rock area

## March 22 Event

A total of 31 tornadoes were confirmed on March 22, including:

* Alabama: 12 tornadoes, including several long-lived EF3 tornadoes that affected several counties
* Georgia: 8 tornadoes, including an EF3 tornado that damaged several homes in the Atlanta area
* Florida: 6 tornadoes, including an EF2 tornado that touched down in the Panama City area
* Tennessee: 3 tornadoes, including an EF1 tornado that damaged several homes in the Chattanooga area
* Kentucky: 2 tornadoes, including an EF1 tornado that touched down in the Lexington area

## March 23 Event

A total of 29 tornadoes were confirmed on March 23, including:

* North Carolina: 12 tornadoes, including a long-lived EF2 tornado that affected several counties
* Virginia: 8 tornadoes, including an EF2 tornado that damaged several homes in the Richmond area
* Maryland: 4 tornadoes, including an EF1 tornado that touched down in the Baltimore area
* South Carolina: 3 tornadoes, including an EF1 tornado that damaged several homes in the Columbia area
* West Virginia: 2 tornadoes, including an EF1 tornado that touched down in the Charleston area

## Gretna–Arabi–New Orleans East, Louisiana

A long-lived EF3 tornado affected the Gretna, Arabi, and New Orleans East areas of Louisiana, causing widespread damage and killing at least one person. The tornado touched down in the late evening hours of March 22 and remained on the ground for approximately 30 miles.

# Non-Tornadic Effects

In addition to the tornadoes, the outbreak produced widespread non-tornadic effects, including:

* Large hail: Multiple reports of large hail were received across the region, including hailstones up to 2 inches in diameter.
* Damaging winds: Strong winds caused widespread damage, including downed trees and power lines.
* Flash flooding: Heavy rainfall caused flash flooding in several areas, including parts of Alabama and Georgia.

# Preparations and Impacts

The outbreak had significant impacts on daily life, including:

* School closures: Multiple school districts closed due to the severe weather threat.
* Flight cancellations: Several flights were cancelled or delayed due to the severe weather.
* Power outages: Widespread power outages were reported across the region, affecting thousands of homes and businesses.

# Aftermath

The aftermath of the outbreak included:

* Search and rescue efforts: Emergency responders conducted search and rescue efforts in affected areas, including the use of drones and K-9 units.
* Damage assessments: Damage assessments were conducted in affected areas, with preliminary estimates suggesting hundreds of millions of dollars in damage.
* Relief efforts: Relief efforts were established, including the distribution of food, water, and shelter to affected individuals.

# See Also

* List of tornado outbreaks
* Tornadoes of 2022
* Storm Prediction Center

# Notes

This article is a factual summary of the tornado outbreak of March 21–23, 2022.

# External Links

* Storm Prediction Center
* National Weather Service
* Federal Emergency Management Agency

The 2022 ICC Women's Cricket World Cup was the 12th edition of the Women's Cricket World Cup, the premier international women's cricket tournament. The tournament was held in New Zealand from 4 March to 3 April 2022. The event was originally scheduled to take place in 2021, but due to the COVID-19 pandemic, it was postponed to 2022.

#Qualification

The qualification process for the 2022 Women's Cricket World Cup was based on the ICC Women's Championship, which was played from 2017 to 2020. article:
Piolets d'Or

The Piolets d'Or (French for "Golden Ice Axes") is an annual mountaineering award honoring outstanding achievements in alpinism and rock climbing. Considered one of the most prestigious awards in the climbing world, the Piolets d'Or recognizes exceptional ascents, innovative routes, and contributions to the sport.

History

The Piolets d'Or was established in 1991 by the French magazine Montagne and the Groupe de Haute Montagne (GHM), a French mountaineering organization. The award was created to recognize and celebrate outstanding achievements in alpinism and rock climbing, with a focus on innovation, style, and commitment. Over the years, the Piolets d'Or has evolved to include multiple winners, new categories, and changes in the selection process.

Multiple winners

Several climbers have won the Piolets d'Or multiple times, including Reinhold Messner, Catherine Destivelle, and Ueli Steck. These repeat winners have demonstrated exceptional skill, dedication, and innovation in their climbing careers.

Criteria

The Piolets d'Or selection process is based on several criteria, including:

* Innovation and creativity in route selection and climbing style
* Difficulty and technical challenge of the ascent
* Commitment and perseverance in the face of adversity
* Respect for the environment and local cultures
* Contribution to the sport of climbing and mountaineering

A jury of experienced climbers, mountaineers, and outdoor enthusiasts reviews nominations and selects the winners based on these criteria.

Reception

The Piolets d'Or has been widely recognized and respected within the climbing community, with many winners going on to achieve international recognition and acclaim. The award has also been praised for its emphasis on innovation, style, and commitment, which are considered essential values in the sport of climbing.

Criticism

Despite its prestige, the Piolets d'Or has faced criticism over the years, with some arguing that the selection process is subjective and biased towards certain types of climbing or climbers. Others have criticized the award for prioritizing flashy, high-profile ascents over quieter, more low-key achievements.

2023 award (31st awards)

The 2023 Piolets d'Or ceremony took place on November 18, 2022, in La Grave, France. The winners of the 31st Piolets d'Or awards were:

* Marc-André Leclerc and Ryan Johnson for their ascent of the Emperor Face on Mount Robson, Canada
* Babsi Gensheimer and Sebastian Brutscher for their ascent of the north face of the Eiger, Switzerland
* Special mention: Emily Harrington for her solo ascent of the Golden Gate route on El Capitan, Yosemite National Park, USA

2022 award (30th awards)

The 2022 Piolets d'Or ceremony took place on November 19, 2021, in La Grave, France. The winners of the 30th Piolets d'Or awards were:

* Alex Honnold and Tommy Caldwell for their ascent of the Fitz Roy Traverse, Patagonia
* Emily Harrington and Adrian Ballinger for their ascent of the southwest face of Everest, Nepal
* Special mention: Eliot Nochez and Louna Ladevant for their ascent of the north face of the Grandes Jorasses, France

The 2021 Piolets d'Or ceremony took place on February 25, 2021, in La Grave, France. The winners of the 29th Piolets d'Or awards were:

* Ethan Pringle and Alex Honnold for their ascent of the Torres Traverse, Patagonia

* Special mention: David Lama for his ascent of the Lunag Ri, Nepal (Lama died in an avalanche on April 16, 2019, while attempting to climb the Howse Peak in the Canadian Rockies)

article:
Attempted Assassination of Imran Khan

The attempted assassination of Imran Khan, the 22nd Prime Minister of Pakistan, occurred on November 3, 2022, in Wazirabad, Punjab, Pakistan. Khan was shot and injured while leading a protest march towards Islamabad, the capital city of Pakistan. The incident sent shockwaves across the country and sparked widespread condemnation from politicians, civil society, and the general public.

# Background

## Ousting of Imran Khan

Imran Khan was ousted as the Prime Minister of Pakistan on April 10, 2022, through a no-confidence vote in the National Assembly. The vote was held after the opposition parties, led by the Pakistan Muslim League (N) and the Pakistan Peoples Party, tabled a no-confidence motion against Khan, citing his government's poor performance and alleged mismanagement of the economy. Khan's Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf (PTI) party had been in power since 2018.

## 2022 Azadi March-II

Following his ouster, Khan announced a nationwide protest march, dubbed the "Azadi March-II," to demand fresh elections and the resignation of the newly appointed Prime Minister, Shehbaz Sharif. The march began on October 28, 2022, from Lahore and was scheduled to culminate in Islamabad on November 4, 2022. Khan and his supporters claimed that the march was a peaceful protest aimed at restoring democracy and the rule of law in Pakistan.

# Shooting

On November 3, 2022, while leading the protest march in Wazirabad, Khan was shot and injured in an assassination attempt. The incident occurred at around 4:30 pm local time when Khan was standing on the container-mounted stage of his convoy. A gunman, later identified as Naveed, opened fire on the convoy, hitting Khan in the leg. The shooting also injured several other PTI leaders and supporters, including Senator Faisal Javed Khan and former Punjab governor Chaudhry Sarwar.

Khan was immediately rushed to a nearby hospital, where he underwent surgery for his injuries. His condition was reported to be stable, and he was later shifted to a hospital in Lahore for further treatment.

# Suspects

The suspect, Naveed, was immediately arrested by the police and taken into custody. According to initial reports, Naveed was a 35-year-old resident of Wazirabad who had been motivated by "personal grievances" against Khan. However, further investigations revealed that Naveed had been influenced by extremist ideologies and had been planning the attack for several months.

The police also arrested several other suspects, including Naveed's brother and a local cleric, in connection with the assassination attempt. The investigation is ongoing, and authorities have promised to bring the perpetrators to justice.

# Reactions

## Domestic

The attempted assassination of Imran Khan sparked widespread outrage and condemnation across Pakistan. Politicians from all major parties, including the ruling coalition, condemned the attack and expressed solidarity with Khan. The Prime Minister, Shehbaz Sharif, ordered an immediate investigation into the incident and vowed to bring the perpetrators to justice.

Civil society and human rights organizations also condemned the attack, calling it a "brazen attempt to silence a political leader." The Pakistan Bar Council, the apex body of lawyers in the country, demanded a thorough investigation and punishment for the perpetrators.

## International

The international community also condemned the assassination attempt, with several countries and organizations expressing solidarity with Khan and the people of Pakistan. The United States, the United Kingdom, and the European Union issued statements condemning the attack and calling for a thorough investigation.

The United Nations Secretary-General, António Guterres, also condemned the attack, expressing concern over the "increasingly violent" political climate in Pakistan. The Organization of Islamic Cooperation (OIC) and the Commonwealth of Nations also issued statements condemning the attack and calling for calm and restraint.

# See also

* Assassination of Salman Taseer
* Assassination of Benazir Bhutto
* 2022 Pakistani constitutional crisis

article:
Banat of Craiova

The Banat of Craiova was a short-lived administrative division of the Habsburg Monarchy, established in 1718 and dissolved in 1739. It was located in the region of Oltenia, in what is now southwestern Romania. The Banat of Craiova was a unique experiment in colonial administration, which had significant consequences for the local population and the region's cultural heritage.

#History

The history of the Banat of Craiova is closely tied to the complex and often tumultuous relations between the Habsburg Monarchy and the Ottoman Empire.

##Austrian conquest

In 1716, during the Great Turkish War, the Habsburg Monarchy, led by Prince Eugene of Savoy, launched a campaign against the Ottoman Empire. The Austrians quickly conquered the region of Oltenia, including the city of Craiova, which became the administrative center of the newly formed Banat. The city's strategic location made it an important hub for trade and commerce, and the Austrians saw it as a key location for expanding their influence in the region.

##Government creation

In 1718, the Habsburg Monarchy established the Banat of Craiova as a separate administrative division, governed by a ban, or viceroy, appointed by the Emperor. The ban was responsible for collecting taxes, maintaining law and order, and overseeing the local economy. The Austrians also introduced a new system of administration, which was based on the principles of Enlightenment absolutism. This system emphasized the importance of rational governance, efficient administration, and economic development.

##Boyar and peasant resistance

The local boyar class, who had traditionally held power and influence in the region, resisted the Austrian conquest and the establishment of the Banat. They saw the Austrians as foreign occupiers who threatened their privileges and way of life. The peasants, who made up the majority of the population, were also skeptical of the Austrians and their new system of administration. Many peasants saw the Austrians as exploiters who imposed heavy taxes and forced labor.

##Austrian consolidation

Despite the initial resistance, the Austrians were able to consolidate their power in the Banat of Craiova. They introduced new laws and regulations, which aimed to modernize the local economy and improve living standards. The Austrians also invested in infrastructure, including roads, bridges, and canals, which helped to stimulate trade and commerce. The city of Craiova became a thriving commercial center, and the region began to experience economic growth.

##Ottoman reconquest

In 1739, during the Austro-Turkish War, the Ottoman Empire reconquered the Banat of Craiova. The Austrians were forced to withdraw, and the region was returned to Ottoman control. The Ottoman reconquest marked the end of the Banat of Craiova as a separate administrative division, and the region was once again governed as part of the Ottoman Empire.

#Legacy

The Banat of Craiova had a lasting impact on the region and its people.

##"Colonial" precedent

The Banat of Craiova was a unique experiment in colonial administration, which set a precedent for future colonial endeavors. The Austrians introduced a new system of administration, which was based on the principles of Enlightenment absolutism. This system emphasized the importance of rational governance, efficient administration, and economic development. The Banat of Craiova served as a model for future colonial administrations, including those established by other European powers.

##Cultural survivals

Despite the Ottoman reconquest, the Banat of Craiova left a lasting cultural legacy in the region. The Austrians introduced new customs, traditions, and institutions, which survived long after the Banat was dissolved. The city of Craiova continued to thrive as a commercial center, and the region experienced economic growth and cultural development. The cultural heritage of the Banat of Craiova can still be seen in the region's architecture, cuisine, and folklore.

#Symbols

The Banat of Craiova had its own symbols, which reflected its unique history and cultural heritage.

* The coat of arms of the Banat of Craiova featured a shield with the imperial eagle of the Habsburg Monarchy, surrounded by the symbols of the region's major cities, including Craiova.
* The flag of the Banat of Craiova featured a white field with the coat of arms in the center.

#Notes

The Banat of Craiova was a short-lived but significant experiment in colonial administration. Its legacy can still be seen in the region's cultural heritage and economic development. article:
FIDE Grand Prix 2022
=====================

The FIDE Grand Prix 2022 was a series of three chess tournaments that took place from February to April 2022. The tournaments were part of the World Chess Championship cycle and featured 24 of the world's top players competing for a share of the prize fund and Grand Prix points. The top two players in the overall standings earned a spot in the Candidates Tournament, which determined the challenger for the World Chess Championship.

Organization
------------

The FIDE Grand Prix 2022 was organized by the World Chess Federation (FIDE) and consisted of three tournaments held in Berlin, Germany, Belgrade, Serbia, and Berlin, Germany. Each tournament featured a round-robin stage followed by a knockout stage.

Players
--------

The 24 players who participated in the FIDE Grand Prix 2022 were:

* 18 players who qualified based on their rating
* 3 players who qualified as wild cards
* 3 players who qualified as nominees of the organizer

Format
-------

### Time controls and tie-breaks

The time control for each game was 90 minutes for the first 40 moves, followed by 30 minutes for the rest of the game, with an increment of 30 seconds per move. In the event of a tie, the following tie-breaks were used:

* 1. Direct encounter
* 2. Sonneborn-Berger score
* 3. Number of wins
* 4. Drawing of lots

### Grand Prix points

The top 8 players in each tournament earned Grand Prix points as follows:

* 1st place: 13 points
* 2nd place: 10 points
* 3rd place: 8 points
* 4th place: 6 points
* 5th place: 5 points
* 6th place: 4 points
* 7th place: 3 points
* 8th place: 2 points

### Prize money

The total prize fund for each tournament was €150,000, with the winner earning €24,000.

Tournament 1 - Berlin, Germany
-----------------------------

The first tournament of the FIDE Grand Prix 2022 took place from February 3 to 17, 2022, in Berlin, Germany.

article:
Vachirawit Chivaaree

Vachirawit Chivaaree, also known as Bright, is a Thai actor, singer, and model who has gained significant recognition in the entertainment industry. Born on December 27, 1997, in Bangkok, Thailand, Bright began his career in the early 2010s and has since become one of the most popular and influential figures in Thai entertainment.

#Early life and education

Vachirawit Chivaaree was born to a Thai father and a Chinese mother. He has two younger siblings, a brother, and a sister. Bright's family owned a small business, and his parents encouraged his interest in the arts from a young age. He began taking piano lessons at the age of five and later became interested in acting and singing.

Bright attended the prestigious Assumption College in Bangkok, where he excelled academically and developed his passion for the arts. He was an active member of the school's drama club and participated in various school plays and musicals. After completing his secondary education, Bright enrolled in the Faculty of Communication Arts at Kasetsart University, where he studied broadcasting and media.

#Career and business ventures

##2013 - 2019: Beginning

Bright began his career in the entertainment industry in 2013, when he joined the Thai talent agency, Channel 3. He started by appearing in small roles on television dramas and variety shows. In 2014, he made his film debut in the Thai horror movie, "Love Sick: The Series." Bright's early work helped him gain recognition and build a small fan base.

##2020: Breakthrough

Bright's breakthrough role came in 2020, when he starred in the Thai television drama, "2gether: The Series," alongside Metawin Opas-iamkajorn. The show became a massive hit, both domestically and internationally, and catapulted Bright to stardom. The drama's success led to a sequel, "Still 2gether," which was released in 2020.

##2021 - 2023: rising popularity

Following the success of "2gether," Bright appeared in several other television dramas, including "F4 Thailand: Boys Over Flowers" and "Astrophile." He also released his debut single, "Lost & Found," in 2021, which became a chart-topper in Thailand. Bright's popularity continued to rise, and he became one of the most sought-after actors in Thai entertainment.

##2024 onwards: present

In 2024, Bright starred in the Thai film, "The Interest," alongside Urassaya Sperbund. The movie became a box office hit, and Bright's performance received critical acclaim. He also released his second single, "Unseen," which debuted at number one on the Thai music charts.

##Business ventures

In 2022, Bright launched his own production company, Bright Vachirawit Co., Ltd. The company aims to produce content for film, television, and digital platforms. Bright has also partnered with several brands to launch his own line of merchandise, including clothing and accessories.

#Artistry

Bright's artistry is characterized by his versatility and range. He has demonstrated his acting abilities in a variety of roles, from romantic comedy to drama. His music style is a blend of pop and rock, with lyrics that often focus on themes of love and self-empowerment.

Bright has cited several artists as inspirations, including Thai singer, Tata Young, and Korean actor, Lee Min-ho. He has also mentioned that he admires the work of Hollywood actors, such as Leonardo DiCaprio and Tom Hiddleston.

#Ambassadorships

##Brand ventures

Bright has partnered with several brands to become their ambassador. In 2020, he became the face of the Thai fashion brand, Karmakamet. He has also partnered with the beauty brand, Pond's, and the technology company, Oppo.

##2024 onwards: present

In 2024, Bright became the ambassador for the Thai tourism board, promoting travel to Thailand. He has also partnered with the environment organization, Greenpeace, to raise awareness about climate change.

##Endorsements

Bright has appeared in several commercials and endorsement campaigns, including ads for Karmakamet, Pond's, and Oppo. He has also partnered with the food delivery service, Grab, and the ride-hailing app, Go-Van.

##Fashion

Bright has become a fashion icon in Thailand, known for his stylish and eclectic sense of fashion. He has walked the red carpet at several high-profile events, including the Thai film awards and the Bangkok Fashion Week.

#Philanthropy

Bright is committed to giving back to his community. He has supported several charitable causes, including the Thai Red Cross and the Children's Hospital. In 2020, he participated in a charity event to raise funds for the COVID-19 pandemic.

#Personal life

##Lifestyle and popularity

Bright's personal life has been the subject of much media attention. He is known to be a private person, but he has shared some details about his lifestyle and interests. He enjoys playing piano, reading, and traveling. Bright has also become known for his sense of humor and his ability to connect with his fans.

#Impact and influence

Bright's impact on the entertainment industry cannot be overstated. He has inspired a new generation of actors and artists, and his influence extends beyond Thailand to other countries in Southeast Asia.

article:
2022 Malaysian General Election

The 2022 Malaysian general election, formally known as the 15th Malaysian general election, was held on November 19, 2022, to elect the members of the 15th Parliament of Malaysia. The election was the first to be held during the COVID-19 pandemic, and it saw a significant shift in the country's political landscape.

#Background

##Previous Election

The previous general election was held on May 9, 2018, which saw the Pakatan Harapan (PH) coalition, led by Mahathir Mohamad, winning a majority of the seats in the Dewan Rakyat, the lower house of the Parliament of Malaysia. The Barisan Nasional (BN) coalition, which had been in power since independence, suffered a significant defeat.

##Significant Events

Several significant events took place between the 2018 and 2022 elections. One of the most notable was the COVID-19 pandemic, which had a major impact on the country's economy and public health. The government's handling of the pandemic was widely criticized, and it led to a significant increase in public dissatisfaction with the government.

Another significant event was the 2020–22 Malaysian political crisis, which saw a series of defections and realignments among the country's political parties. The crisis began in February 2020, when a group of PH lawmakers defected to the BN coalition, triggering a collapse of the PH government.

##2020–22 Political Crisis

The 2020–22 Malaysian political crisis was a period of significant turmoil in the country's politics. It began on February 21, 2020, when a group of PH lawmakers, led by Muhyiddin Yassin, defected to the BN coalition. The defection triggered a collapse of the PH government, and Muhyiddin was appointed as the new Prime Minister.

However, the new government faced significant opposition from the PH coalition, which claimed that the defection was unconstitutional. The crisis continued for several months, with both sides engaging in a series of negotiations and maneuvers.

Eventually, the crisis subsided, and a new government was formed. However, the crisis had a significant impact on the country's politics, leading to a period of instability and realignment among the country's political parties.

#Electoral System

Malaysia uses a first-past-the-post electoral system, in which the candidate with the most votes in each constituency wins the seat. The country is divided into 222 constituencies, each of which elects one member to the Dewan Rakyat.

The electoral system has been criticized for being biased towards the ruling coalition, which has traditionally been the BN coalition. The system has also been criticized for being prone to gerrymandering, which is the manipulation of constituency boundaries to favor one party or group.

#Timeline

##Dissolution of Parliament

The 14th Parliament of Malaysia was dissolved on October 10, 2022, after the Yang di-Pertuan Agong (King of Malaysia) granted the Prime Minister's request for a dissolution.

##Dissolution of State Legislatures

Several state legislatures were also dissolved, including those in the states of Kelantan, Terengganu, Kedah, and Perlis.

##Pre-Nomination Events

Several events took place before the nomination of candidates, including the announcement of the election date and the dissolution of the Parliament.

##Timetable

The election timetable was as follows:

* October 10, 2022: Dissolution of Parliament
* October 20, 2022: Nomination of candidates
* November 5, 2022: Early voting
* November 19, 2022: Polling day

#Last Election Pendulum

The last election pendulum shows the number of seats that each party or coalition needs to win to form a government. The pendulum is based on the results of the 2018 general election.

#Political Parties and Candidates

##Parties Represented in Current Legislatures

Several parties are represented in the current legislatures, including the BN coalition, the PH coalition, and the Pan-Malaysian Islamic Party (PAS).

##Extra-Parliamentary Parties

Several extra-parliamentary parties also contested the election, including the Malaysian United Democratic Alliance (MUDA) and the Parti Pejuang Tanah Air (Pejuang).

##Nominated Candidates

A total of 916 candidates were nominated for the election, including several high-profile politicians.

#Campaign

##Timing of Election

The election was held during the COVID-19 pandemic, which had a significant impact on the campaign. Several candidates and parties were forced to adapt their campaign strategies to comply with health protocols.

##Youth Vote

The youth vote was seen as a key factor in the election, with several parties and candidates targeting young voters through social media and other channels.

#Outgoing Members of Parliament

Several outgoing members of Parliament did not contest the election, including the former Prime Minister, Mahathir Mohamad.

#Opinion Polls

Several opinion polls were conducted during the campaign, with some showing a close contest between the main parties.

#Results

##By Alliance

The results by alliance were as follows:

* Pakatan Harapan (PH) coalition: 81 seats
* Perikatan Nasional (PN) coalition: 73 seats
* Barisan Nasional (BN) coalition: 30 seats
* Gabungan Parti Sarawak (GPS) coalition: 23 seats
* Gabungan Rakyat Sabah (GRS) coalition: 6 seats
* Independents: 2 seats

##By Parliamentary Seats

The results by parliamentary seat were as follows:

* Pakatan Harapan (PH) coalition: 81 seats
* Perikatan Nasional (PN) coalition: 73 seats
* Barisan Nasional (BN) coalition: 30 seats
* Gabungan Parti Sarawak (GPS) coalition: 23 seats
* Gabungan Rakyat Sabah (GRS) coalition: 6 seats
* Independents: 2 seats

##State Assemblies

The results for the state assemblies were as follows:

* Pakatan Harapan (PH) coalition: 270 seats
* Perikatan Nasional (PN) coalition: 209 seats
* Barisan Nasional (BN) coalition: 114 seats
* Gabungan Parti Sarawak (GPS) coalition: 76 seats
* Gabungan Rakyat Sabah (GRS) coalition: 29 seats
* Independents: 10 seats

##Seats that Changed Allegiance

Several seats changed allegiance during the election, including the parliamentary seat of Pekan, which was won by the PN coalition.

#Aftermath

##Formation of Federal Government

The formation of the federal government was delayed due to a dispute over the appointment of the Prime Minister.

##International Reactions

The international community reacted cautiously to the election results, with several countries calling for a peaceful transfer of power.

#See Also

* 2022 Malaysian state elections
* List of members of the Dewan Rakyat
* List of members of the Dewan Negara

#Notes

2023 FIFA Women's World Cup

The 2023 FIFA Women's World Cup was the ninth edition of the FIFA Women's World Cup, the quadrennial international women's football championship contested by the national teams of the member associations of FIFA. The tournament was held in Australia and New Zealand from 20 July to 20 August 2023.

# Overview

The 2023 FIFA Women's World Cup was a groundbreaking event in the history of women's football, with a record-breaking number of teams participating and a significant increase in prize money. The tournament featured 32 national teams, with several teams making their World Cup debut. The event was also notable for its commitment to sustainability and social responsibility.

## Schedule

The tournament schedule was announced in December 2020, with the final match taking place on 20 August 2023. The group stage matches were played from 20 July to 3 August, followed by the knockout stage from 5 to 20 August.

## Prize money

The total prize money for the tournament was $110 million, a significant increase from the $30 million awarded in the previous edition. The winner of the tournament received $22 million, while the runner-up received $11 million.

# Host selection

Australia and New Zealand were jointly awarded the hosting rights for the 2023 FIFA Women's World Cup in June 2020. The two countries submitted a joint bid, which was successful in defeating Colombia's bid.

# Format

The tournament featured 32 national teams, divided into eight groups of four teams each. The top two teams from each group advanced to the knockout stage, which consisted of a round of 16, quarter-finals, semi-finals, and the final.

# Venues

A total of 10 stadiums across Australia and New Zealand were selected as venues for the tournament. The stadiums were:

* Australia: Sydney Football Stadium, Melbourne Rectangular Stadium, Brisbane Stadium, Perth Stadium, and Hindmarsh Stadium
* New Zealand: Eden Park, Wellington Regional Stadium, Waikato Stadium, Dunedin Stadium, and Christchurch Stadium

# Teams

## Qualification

A total of 172 national teams entered the qualification process for the 2023 FIFA Women's World Cup. The qualification process began in 2021 and ended in 2023, with several teams securing their spots through various confederation tournaments and playoffs.

## Squads

Each participating team was required to submit a squad of 23 players, including three goalkeepers. The squads were announced in June 2023.

## Draw

The draw for the 2023 FIFA Women's World Cup took place on 22 October 2022. The teams were divided into eight groups of four teams each, with the top two teams from each group advancing to the knockout stage.

# Officiating

A total of 19 referees and 33 assistant referees were selected for the tournament. The referees were from various confederations and had extensive experience in officiating international matches.

# Ceremonies

## Opening ceremonies

The opening ceremony took place on 20 July 2023 at the Auckland Stadium in New Zealand. The ceremony featured a cultural performance, a welcome message from the Prime Minister of New Zealand, and the official opening of the tournament.

## Closing ceremonies

The closing ceremony took place on 20 August 2023 at the Sydney Football Stadium in Australia. The ceremony featured a cultural performance, a farewell message from the President of FIFA, and the official closing of the tournament.

# Impact

article:
2021 SEA Games

The 2021 Southeast Asian Games, officially known as the 31st Southeast Asian Games, was a regional multi-sport event that took place in Hanoi, Vietnam from 12 to 23 May 2022. The games were originally scheduled to take place from 21 November to 2 December 2021 but were postponed due to the COVID-19 pandemic.

# Host selection

The host selection process for the 2021 Southeast Asian Games began in 2012, when the Southeast Asian Games Federation (SEAGF) announced that it would be accepting bids for the 31st edition of the games.

## Hanoi

Hanoi, the capital city of Vietnam, was one of the two cities that bid to host the 2021 Southeast Asian Games. Hanoi's bid was led by the Vietnam Olympic Committee and the Hanoi People's Committee. The bid highlighted Hanoi's experience in hosting major international events, including the 2003 Southeast Asian Games and the 2009 Asian Indoor Games.

## Ho Chi Minh City

Ho Chi Minh City, the largest city in Vietnam, was the other city that bid to host the 2021 Southeast Asian Games. Ho Chi Minh City's bid was led by the Ho Chi Minh City People's Committee and the Vietnam Olympic Committee. The bid emphasized Ho Chi Minh City's modern infrastructure and its ability to host large-scale events.

## Decision

The host selection process was concluded on November 22, 2012, when the SEAGF announced that Hanoi would host the 2021 Southeast Asian Games. The decision was made after a thorough evaluation of the bids submitted by Hanoi and Ho Chi Minh City.

# Postponement

The 2021 Southeast Asian Games were originally scheduled to take place from 21 November to 2 December 2021. However, due to the COVID-19 pandemic, the games were postponed to 2022. The new dates for the games were announced on July 8, 2021, when the SEAGF announced that the games would take place from 12 to 23 May 2022.

# Preparation

The preparation for the 2021 Southeast Asian Games began in 2018, when the Vietnam Olympic Committee and the Hanoi People's Committee established the Organizing Committee for the 2021 Southeast Asian Games.

## Budget

The budget for the 2021 Southeast Asian Games was estimated to be around VND 2.25 trillion (approximately USD 100 million). The budget was allocated for the construction of new venues, the upgrade of existing venues, and the organization of the games.

## Venues

A total of 18 venues were used for the 2021 Southeast Asian Games. The venues were located in Hanoi and the surrounding provinces.

### Non-competition venues

In addition to the competition venues, several non-competition venues were also used for the games. These included the Athletes' Village, the International Broadcasting Center, and the Main Press Center.

## Volunteers

A total of 10,000 volunteers were recruited for the 2021 Southeast Asian Games. The volunteers were responsible for various tasks, including spectator services, transportation, and language support.

## Torch relay

The torch relay for the 2021 Southeast Asian Games began on April 6, 2022, and concluded on May 11, 2022. The torch relay covered a distance of over 3,000 kilometers and passed through 10 provinces in Vietnam.

## Ticketing

Tickets for the 2021 Southeast Asian Games went on sale on April 15, 2022. The ticket prices ranged from VND 50,000 to VND 500,000 (approximately USD 2 to USD 20).

## Medals

The medals for the 2021 Southeast Asian Games were designed by the Vietnam Olympic Committee. The medals featured the logo of the games and the national emblem of Vietnam.

# The Games

The 2021 Southeast Asian Games officially opened on May 12, 2022, with a ceremony at the My Dinh National Stadium in Hanoi.

## COVID-19 regulations

Due to the COVID-19 pandemic, several regulations were put in place to ensure the safety of the athletes and spectators. These included mandatory vaccination, wearing of masks, and social distancing.

## Opening ceremony

The opening ceremony of the 2021 Southeast Asian Games took place on May 12, 2022, at the My Dinh National Stadium in Hanoi. The ceremony featured a cultural show, the parade of nations, and the lighting of the cauldron.

### Welcome, national flag and anthem

The ceremony began with the welcome speech by the Prime Minister of Vietnam, Pham Minh Chinh. This was followed by the raising of the national flag and the playing of the national anthem.

### Parade of Nations

The parade of nations took place next, with the athletes from the 11 participating countries marching into the stadium. The athletes were led by their respective national flags and were accompanied by their national anthems.

## Closing ceremony

The closing ceremony of the 2021 Southeast Asian Games took place on May 23, 2022, at the My Dinh National Stadium in Hanoi. The ceremony featured a cultural show, the extinguishing of the cauldron, and the handing over of the SEAGF flag to the next host country.

## Participating nations

A total of 11 countries participated in the 2021 Southeast Asian Games. These included Brunei, Cambodia, Indonesia, Laos, Malaysia, Myanmar, the Philippines, Singapore, Thailand, Timor-Leste, and Vietnam.

## Sports

A total of 40 sports were featured in the 2021 Southeast Asian Games. These included aquatics, athletics, badminton, basketball, billiards and snooker, boxing, canoeing, chess, cycling, esports, fencing, football, golf, gymnastics, handball, hockey, judo, karate, kickboxing, kurash, muay thai, pencak silat, petanque, rowing, sailing, sepak takraw, shooting, skateboarding, softball, squash, surfing, table tennis, taekwondo, tennis, triathlon, volleyball, weightlifting, wrestling, and wushu.

## Calendar

The competition calendar for the 2021 Southeast Asian Games was from May 12 to May 23, 2022. The calendar featured a total of 523 events across the 40 sports.

# Medal table

The medal table for the 2021 Southeast Asian Games was topped by Vietnam, which won a total of 205 medals, including 92 gold medals. Indonesia came second with a total of 137 medals, including 69 gold medals. Thailand came third with a total of 126 medals, including 41 gold medals.

# Notable occurrences

The 2021 Southeast Asian Games saw several notable occurrences, including the first-ever esports competition and the introduction of new sports such as skateboarding and surfing.

# Marketing

The marketing campaign for the 2021 Southeast Asian Games was launched in 2020, with the slogan "For a Stronger Southeast Asia".

## Official branding

The official branding for the 2021 Southeast Asian Games included the logo, mascot, slogan, and theme song.

### Logo

The logo for the 2021 Southeast Asian Games featured the national emblem of Vietnam surrounded by 11 circles, representing the 11 participating countries.

### Mascot

The mascot for the 2021 Southeast Asian Games was a symbolic representation of the mythical creature, the Long. The mascot was named Sao La and was designed to represent the spirit of the games.

### Slogan

The slogan for the 2021 Southeast Asian Games was "For a Stronger Southeast Asia". The slogan emphasized the importance of unity and solidarity among the participating countries.

### Theme song

The theme song for the 2021 Southeast Asian Games was titled "For a Stronger Southeast Asia". The song was performed by several Vietnamese artists and was played during the opening and closing ceremonies.

## Sponsors

The 2021 Southeast Asian Games had several sponsors, including the Vietnam Lottery Company, the Vietnam National Administration of Tourism, and the Vietnam Posts and Telecommunications Group.

# Live Broadcasting rights

The live broadcasting rights for the 2021 Southeast Asian Games were held by the Vietnam Television Corporation (VTV). VTV broadcast the games live on its various channels, including VTV1, VTV2, and VTV6.

# Notes

The 2021 Southeast Asian Games were the 31st edition of the games and marked the second time that Vietnam had hosted the event.

article:
2022 Nepalese local elections

The 2022 Nepalese local elections were held on May 13, 2022, to elect representatives to local government bodies in Nepal. The elections were the second local elections to be held in the country since the adoption of the new constitution in 2015. A total of 35,221 candidates contested for 35,221 positions in 753 local government bodies, including six metropolitan cities, 11 sub-metropolitan cities, 276 municipalities, and 460 rural municipalities.

# Electoral system

The electoral system used in the 2022 Nepalese local elections was a mixed system, with both first-past-the-post and proportional representation components. The elections were held in two phases: the first phase was held on May 13, 2022, and the second phase was held on June 23, 2022.

## Qualification for candidates

To be eligible to contest in the elections, candidates had to meet certain qualifications. For example, they had to be citizens of Nepal, be at least 25 years old, and have a certain level of education. Additionally, candidates had to be resident in the ward or municipality they were contesting in.

## Exit poll

Exit polls were conducted by various organizations to gauge the mood of the voters. The exit polls suggested that the Nepali Congress and the Communist Party of Nepal (Unified Marxist-Leninist) (CPN-UML) were the two largest parties in the elections. However, the exit polls also suggested that the Communist Party of Nepal (Maoist Centre) (CPN-MC) and the Janata Samajbadi Party (JSP) had performed well in certain areas.

### Mayor/Chairperson post

The mayor/chairperson post was the most contested position in the elections, with a total of 753 candidates vying for the post. The Nepali Congress and the CPN-UML were the two largest parties in the mayoral elections, with the Nepali Congress winning 195 mayoral seats and the CPN-UML winning 184 mayoral seats.

# Results

Piri

Piri is a British singer, songwriter, and record producer. Born and raised in Manchester, England, Piri rose to prominence in the music industry with her unique blend of genres and emotive songwriting.

# Life and career

## 1999–2020: Early life

Piri was born in 1999 in Manchester, England. Growing up in a musical family, she was exposed to a wide range of genres and artists from a young age. She began writing her own music as a teenager, drawing inspiration from the likes of Elliott Smith and Joni Mitchell. Piri's early life was marked by a strong passion for music, which would eventually lead her to pursue a career in the industry.

## 2020–present: Piri & Tommy

In 2020, Piri began collaborating with producer and songwriter Tommy Villiers, with whom she formed the duo Piri & Tommy. The pair's music quickly gained traction online, with their unique blend of indie rock, electronic, and pop elements resonating with listeners. Piri & Tommy's breakout single, "Soft Spot", was released in 2020 to critical acclaim, with praise from publications such as NME and The Fader.

## 2022–present: Other works

In 2022, Piri began exploring solo projects outside of her work with Tommy Villiers. She released her debut solo single, "Beach", which showcased her ability to craft introspective and emotionally charged songs. Piri has also collaborated with other artists, including producers and songwriters from the UK and beyond.

# Artistry

## Influences, voice, and songwriting

Piri's music is characterized by her distinctive vocal style, which blends elements of indie rock and electronic music. Her songwriting is often introspective and emotionally charged, drawing on personal experiences and observations. Piri has cited a range of influences, including Elliott Smith, Joni Mitchell, and Burial. Her music often incorporates elements of folk, rock, and pop, with a strong emphasis on atmospheric production and introspective lyrics.

## Music videos and stage

Piri's music videos often feature striking visuals and narrative-driven storytelling. Her videos for "Soft Spot" and "Beach" have garnered significant attention online, with praise from publications such as Dazed and The Line of Best Fit. Piri has also performed live with Piri & Tommy, with the duo's energetic and emotive live shows earning praise from critics and fans alike.

# Personal life

Piri is based in Manchester, England, where she continues to write and produce music. She is active on social media, where she engages with fans and shares updates on her music and personal life.

# Awards and accolades

## Lists

Piri has been featured on a range of lists and playlists, including the BBC Sound of 2022 longlist and the NME 100. Her music has also been featured on popular playlists such as Spotify's New Music Friday and Apple Music's A-List.

# Discography

Chandramukhi 2 is expected to be a major release in the Indian film industry, with fans eagerly awaiting its arrival in theaters.

#Plot

The story takes place several years after the events of the original movie and follows a new set of characters who become entangled in Chandramukhi's web of revenge. The movie promises to deliver a mix of horror, comedy, and drama, with plenty of twists and turns to keep audiences on the edge of their seats.

According to director P. Vasu, the film will explore the backstory of Chandramukhi and delve deeper into the mythology surrounding the character. ##Filming

The movie was shot on location in a number of different places, including Chennai and Hyderabad. The film's cinematography was handled by R.D. Rajasekhar, who worked closely with Vasu to create a unique and atmospheric visual style.

The movie's soundtrack features a number of haunting and atmospheric tracks, each one perfectly capturing the mood and tone of the film. Qatar Corruption Scandal at the European Parliament

The Qatar corruption scandal at the European Parliament refers to a major corruption scandal that came to light in December 2022, involving several high-ranking officials of the European Parliament, including a Vice-President, and their alleged acceptance of bribes from Qatar and Morocco in exchange for influencing European Union policy.

# Allegations and Events Leading Up to the Arrests

The scandal began to unfold in June 2022, when the Belgian Federal Police launched an investigation into allegations of corruption and money laundering involving several European Parliament officials. The investigation, led by the Belgian prosecutor's office, focused on the alleged acceptance of bribes from Qatar and Morocco by several high-ranking officials, including Eva Kaili, a Greek Member of the European Parliament (MEP) and Vice-President of the European Parliament.

According to reports, the investigation was triggered by a tip-off from an anonymous source, who alleged that several MEPs had accepted bribes from Qatari officials in exchange for promoting Qatari interests within the European Parliament. The investigation also focused on the alleged involvement of Moroccan officials in the bribery scheme.

# Investigation, Raids, and Arrests

On December 9, 2022, the Belgian Federal Police launched a series of raids on the homes and offices of several MEPs, including Eva Kaili, as part of the ongoing investigation. The raids resulted in the seizure of large sums of cash, as well as computer equipment and documents.

Bigg Boss (Telugu TV series) season 7

Bigg Boss Telugu season 7 is the seventh season of the Telugu version of the Indian reality television series Bigg Boss, produced by Endemol Shine India and broadcast on Star Maa. The show premiered on 3 September 2023 and concluded on 31 December 2023. Nagarjuna Akkineni returned as the host for the fourth consecutive season.

# Production

## Eye Logo

The eye logo of Bigg Boss Telugu season 7 was revealed on 30 July 2023. The logo features a futuristic design with a mix of blue and red colors, symbolizing the theme of the season, "Future is here".

## Concept

The concept of Bigg Boss Telugu season 7 revolves around the theme "Future is here". The show features a futuristic setup, with a house designed to resemble a space station. The contestants, known as "housemates", live together in the house with cameras and microphones recording their every move.

## 24x7 streaming

Bigg Boss Telugu season 7 is available for 24x7 streaming on the Disney+ Hotstar app. Viewers can watch the live feed of the show on the app, as well as exclusive content and unseen footage.

article:
Naagin (2015 TV series)

Naagin is a popular Indian supernatural fantasy drama television series that premiered on 1 November 2015 on Colors TV. The show was produced by Ekta Kapoor and Shobha Kapoor under the banner of Balaji Telefilms. The series revolves around the story of a female shape-shifting serpent, Naagin, who seeks revenge for her lover's death.

# Series overview

Naagin is a story of a female shape-shifting serpent, Naagin, who seeks revenge for her lover's death. The series explores the concept of reincarnation, love, and revenge. The show features a mix of mythology, drama, and romance, making it a unique and captivating watch.

# Plot

## Season 1

The first season of Naagin premiered on 1 November 2015 and concluded on 5 June 2016. The story revolves around Shivanya (Mouni Roy), a shape-shifting serpent who seeks revenge for her lover's death. Shivanya marries Ritik Singh (Arjun Bijlani), a wealthy businessman, to avenge her lover's death. However, she soon falls in love with Ritik and decides to give up her revenge plan. The season features a mix of drama, romance, and supernatural elements.

## Season 2

The second season of Naagin premiered on 8 October 2016 and concluded on 25 June 2017. The story takes a leap of 25 years and introduces a new protagonist, Shivangi (Mouni Roy), who is Shivanya's daughter. Shivangi seeks revenge for her mother's death and marries Rocky Singh (Karanvir Bohra), a wealthy businessman. However, she soon falls in love with Rocky and decides to give up her revenge plan. The season features a mix of drama, romance, and supernatural elements.

## Season 3

The third season of Naagin premiered on 2 June 2018 and concluded on 26 May 2019. The story revolves around Bela (Surbhi Jyoti), a shape-shifting serpent who seeks revenge for her lover's death. Bela marries Mahir Sehgal (Pearl V Puri), a wealthy businessman, to avenge her lover's death. However, she soon falls in love with Mahir and decides to give up her revenge plan. The season features a mix of drama, romance, and supernatural elements.

## Season 4

The fourth season of Naagin premiered on 14 December 2019 and concluded on 8 August 2020. The story revolves around Brinda (Nia Sharma), a shape-shifting serpent who seeks revenge for her lover's death. Brinda marries Dev Parikh (Vijayendra Kumeria), a wealthy businessman, to avenge her lover's death. However, she soon falls in love with Dev and decides to give up her revenge plan. The season features a mix of drama, romance, and supernatural elements.

## Season 5

The fifth season of Naagin premiered on 9 August 2020 and concluded on 6 February 2021. The story takes a leap of 1 year and introduces a new protagonist, Bani (Surbhi Chandna), who is a shape-shifting eagle. Bani seeks revenge for her lover's death and marries Veeranshu Singhania (Sharad Malhotra), a wealthy businessman. However, she soon falls in love with Veeranshu and decides to give up her revenge plan. The season features a mix of drama, romance, and supernatural elements.

## Basant Panchami Special

A special episode of Naagin was aired on 29 January 2021, which featured a mix of drama, romance, and supernatural elements.

## Season 6

The sixth season of Naagin premiered on 12 February 2022 and is currently airing on Colors TV. The story revolves around Pratha (Tejasswi Prakash), a shape-shifting serpent who seeks revenge for her lover's death. Pratha marries Rishabh Gujral (Simba Nagpal), a wealthy businessman, to avenge her lover's death. However, she soon falls in love with Rishabh and decides to give up her revenge plan. The season features a mix of drama, romance, and supernatural elements.

article:
Bhool Bhulaiyaa 2

Bhool Bhulaiyaa 2 is a 2022 Indian Hindi-language comedy horror film directed by Anees Bazmee and produced by Bhushan Kumar and Krishan Kumar under the banner of T-Series Films. The film is a standalone sequel to the 2007 film Bhool Bhulaiyaa and stars Kartik Aaryan, Kiara Advani, and Tabu in lead roles.

#Plot

The film follows the story of Ruhaan Randhawa (Kartik Aaryan), a charming and confident guy who falls in love with Reet Thakur (Kiara Advani) in a foreign land. However, their love is put to the test when Reet's family gets her engaged to another man. In a twist of fate, Ruhaan arrives in India and meets Reet's family, including her cousin, Potri (Tabu), who is a strict and traditional woman.

As Ruhaan tries to win over Reet's family, he discovers that the family is hiding a dark secret. The family's ancestral mansion is believed to be haunted by the ghost of Manjulika, a woman who was wronged by the family in the past. Ruhaan, being a non-believer, decides to explore the mansion and uncover the truth behind the haunting.

However, things take a turn when Ruhaan discovers that he has a connection to the family's past and that he is the key to unlocking the secrets of the mansion. As Ruhaan delves deeper into the mystery, he must confront his own demons and face the evil forces that are haunting the family.

#Cast

* Kartik Aaryan as Ruhaan Randhawa
* Kiara Advani as Reet Thakur
* Tabu as Potri Bahu
* Rajpal Yadav as Chhote Pandit
* Sanjay Mishra as Bade Pandit
* Ashwini Kalsekar as Laxmi
* Karmveer Choudhary as Ajay
* Manoj Joshi as Shrikant Thakur
* Rajesh Sharma as Ramakant Randhawa

#Production

##Development

The film was announced in 2019, with Kartik Aaryan and Kiara Advani starring in the lead roles. The film was initially titled Bhool Bhulaiyaa 3, but later changed to Bhool Bhulaiyaa 2. The film's script was written by Anees Bazmee and Akash Kaushik.

##Filming

The film's principal photography began in October 2019 and was wrapped up in February 2020. The film was shot in various locations, including Mumbai, Jaipur, and Rajasthan. The film's climax was shot in a single take, with Kartik Aaryan performing a 10-minute long sequence without any cuts.

#Release

##Theatrical

The film was released on May 20, 2022, in theaters across India. The film received a U/A certificate from the Central Board of Film Certification.

##Home media

The film was released on Netflix on June 19, 2022. The film's digital rights were acquired by Netflix for a reported amount of ₹100 crore.

#Soundtrack

The film's soundtrack was composed by Pritam, Tanishk Bagchi, and Sandeep Shirodkar. The film's songs were written by Amitabh Bhattacharya, Sameer Anjaan, and Rashmi Virag. The film's title track, "Bhool Bhulaiyaa 2", was sung by Neeraj Shridhar and Mellow D.

#Reception

##Critical response

The film received mixed reviews from critics, with many praising the film's performances, music, and direction. Kartik Aaryan's performance was particularly praised, with many calling it his best performance to date. However, some critics felt that the film's script was weak and that the film's climax was predictable.

##Box office

The film was a commercial success, grossing over ₹200 crore at the domestic box office. The film's opening weekend collection was ₹55 crore, making it one of the highest opening weekends of 2022. The film's overseas collection was ₹50 crore, making it a total worldwide gross of ₹250 crore.

#Sequel

A sequel to the film was announced in 2022, with Kartik Aaryan and Kiara Advani reprising their roles. The film's script is currently being written, and the film is expected to go into production in 2023.
